revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2014}} {{Year nav topic5|1591|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1591'''.
==Events== *May – A dispute with [[James Burbage]] impels the [[Admiral's Men]] to leave [[The Theatre]] and move to [[Philip Henslowe]]'s [[The Rose (theatre)|Rose Theatre]] in London. *Summer – Sir [[Walter Ralegh]] secretly marries [[Elizabeth Raleigh|Elizabeth Throckmorton]]. *[[October 4]] – [[John Lyly]]'s ''[[Midas (Lyly play)|Midas]]'' is entered in the [[Stationers' Register]]. *[[November 8]] – Publisher [[Thomas Millington (publisher)|Thomas Millington]] becomes a "freeman" (full member) of the [[Stationers' Company]]. *Poet and historian [[Andrea Cornaro (poet and historian)|Andrea Cornaro]] founds in Candia (modern-day [[Heraklion]] on [[Crete]]) the philological academy ''L’Accademia degli Stravaganti'' ("Academy of the Strange"),<ref>{{cite book|first=Giambattista|last=Basile|title=Lo cunto de li cunti|year=1891|page=36}}</ref> his brother, poet [[Vitsentzos Kornaros]], being among the other members. *Publication of the first of the [[Conimbricenses]] commentaries on [[Aristotle]] by the [[Jesuits]] of the [[University of Coimbra]], ''Commentarii Collegii Conimbricensis Societatis Jesu in octo libros physicorum Aristotelis Stagyritæ'', on Aristotle's ''[[Physics (Aristotle)|Physics]]''.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Andrea Alciato]] – ''Emblemata'' *[[Robert Greene (16th century)|Robert Greene]] – ''Greene's Farewell to Folly'' *[[John Greenwood (Puritan)|John Greenwood]] – ''A Breife Refutation of Mr George Giffard, etc.'' *[[Melis Stoke]] – ''Rijmkroniek'' (History of the Netherlands, written in the 14th century) *"A. W." – ''A Book of Cookrye''
===Children=== *Anonymous – ''A Pretty and Splendid Maiden's Mirror'' (in Swedish){{cn|date=July 2016}}
==Drama== *Anonymous **''[[Fair Em|Fair Em, the Miller's Daughter of Manchester]]'' (approximate date of first performance) **''[[Mucedorus]]'' (approximate date of first performance) **''[[The Troublesome Reign of King John]]'' (perhaps by [[George Peele]]; published) *[[John Lyly]] – ''[[Endymion (play)|Endymion, the Man in the Moon]]'' (published) *[[Muretus]] – ''Julius Caesar'' (published) *[[ Robert Wilmot (playwright)|Robert Wilmot]] – ''Tancred and Gismund'' (published)
===Poetry=== {{main|1591 in poetry}} *[[John Harington (inventor)|Sir John Harington]] – ''Orlando Furioso in English Heroical Verse'' *[[James VI of Scotland]] – ''Lepanto'' *Sir [[Philip Sidney]] (died 1586) – ''[[Astrophel and Stella]]''
==Births== *[[March 6]] – [[Tommaso Tamburini]], Italian Jesuit theologian (died [[1675 in literature|1675]]) *August – [[Robert Herrick (poet)|Robert Herrick]], English poet (died [[1674 in literature|1674]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Thomas Goffe]], English dramatist (died [[1629 in literature|1629]]) **[[Ivan Bunić Vučić]], [[Republic of Ragusa|Ragusa]] poet (died [[1658 in literature|1658]])
==Deaths== *[[February 28]] – [[Arthur Faunt]], English Jesuit missionary (born [[1554 in literature|1554]]) *[[July 7]] – [[Noël du Fail]], French short story writer (born c. 1520) *[[July 22]] – [[Veronica Franco]], Venetian poet and courtesan (born [[1546 in literature|1546]]) *[[August 23]] – [[Luis de León]], Castilian poet, theologian and orator (born [[1527 in literature|1527]]) *[[December 21]] – [[John of the Cross]], Castilian poet and friar (born [[1542 in literature|1542]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Johann Fischart]], German satirist (born c. 1545)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1591 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1742|literature|poetry}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1742'''.
==Events== *February – [[Henry Fielding]]'s [[picaresque novel]] ''[[Joseph Andrews]]'' ("''The History of the Adventures of Joseph Andrews and of his Friend Mr. Abraham Adams'', written in imitation of the manner of Cervantes, author of ''Don Quixote''") is published anonymously in London. Described by Fielding as a "comic epic poem in prose", it is his first full-length novel and one of the earliest in the English language. A second edition is published on June 10. *[[December 2]] – ''[[The Pennsylvania Journal]]'' first appears in the United States. *Irish portraitist [[Charles Jervas]]' English translation of ''[[Don Quixote]]'' is published three years after his death. Through a printer's error, the translator's name is printed as "Charles Jarvis", leading to the book being known forever as the "Jarvis" translation. It is acclaimed as the most faithful English rendering of the novel made up to this time. *The ''[[Stockholm Gazette]]'', founded by [[Margareta Momma|Peter Momma]], begins publication. *Publisher [[Robert Foulis (printer)|Robert Foulis]] acquires his own printing press in [[Glasgow]]. *French [[Type foundry|typefounder]] [[Pierre Simon Fournier]]'s ''Modèles des Caractères'' presents his system of [[Point (typography)|point size]]s for [[typography]].<ref>{{cite journal|first=R. C.|last=Elliott|title=The development if the ‘point’ unit of type measurement|journal=Monotype Recorder|year=1933|volume=30|issue=241|publisher=The Monotype Corporation|location=London|oclc=11494675}}</ref> *[[Pierre de Marivaux]] is elected to the [[Académie française]].
==New books== ===Fiction=== *[[Claude Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon]] – ''[[The Sofa: A Moral Tale]] (Le Sopha, conte moral)'' *[[Henry Fielding]] – ''[[Joseph Andrews]]'' *[[Eliza Haywood]] – ''The Virtuous Villager'' *[[Charles Jervas]] (translator) – ''[[Don Quixote]]''
===Drama=== *[[Charlotte Charke]] – ''Tit for Tat'' *[[Charles Jennens]] – libretto for [[Messiah (Handel)|Handel's ''Messiah'']] *[[José de Cañizares]] – ''El anillo de Giges'' *[[Ignacio de Luzán]] – ''La virtud coronada''
===Poetry=== *[[William Collins (poet)|William Collins]] – ''Persian Eclogues'' *[[Thomas Cooke (author)|Thomas Cooke]] – ''Original Poems'' *[[James Hammond (author)|James Hammond]] – ''Love Elegies'' *[[James Merrick]] – ''The Destruction of Troy'' *'Jorge Pitillas' (José Gerardo Hervás) – ''Sátira contra los malos escritores de este siglo'' *[[William Shenstone]] – ''The School-Mistress'' *[[William Somervile]] – ''Field Sports'' *[[Charles Hanbury Williams]] – ''The Country Girl: An ode'' *[[Edward Young]] – ''[[Night Thoughts (poem)|Night Thoughts]]''
===Non-fiction=== *[[Colley Cibber]] – ''A Letter from Mr. Cibber to Mr. Pope'' (in re [[Alexander Pope|Pope's]] satirizing of Cibber) *[[Ignacio de Luzán]] – ''Carta en defensa de España'' *[[Philip Doddridge]] – ''Evidences of Christianity'' *[[Pierre Simon Fournier]] – ''Modèles des Caractères'' *[[David Hume]] – ''Essays Moral and Political'' vol. ii *[[Benito Jerónimo Feijoo]] – ''Cartas eruditas y curiosas'' *[[Colin Maclaurin]] – ''Treatise on Fluxions'' *[[John Oldmixon]] – ''Memoirs of the Press, Historical and Political'' *[[Horace Walpole]] and Sir Charles Hanbury Williams – ''The Lessons for the Day'' (satire on [[William Pulteney, 1st Earl of Bath|William Pulteney]], [[Henry St. John, 1st Viscount Bolingbroke|Bolingbroke]] and the "[[Patriot Whigs]]"). *[[William Warburton]] – ''A Critical and Philosophical Commentary on Mr. Pope's Essay on Man'' *[[John Wesley]] **''The Character of a [[Methodism|Methodist]]'' **''The Principles of a Methodist'' *[[George Whitefield]] – ''Nine Sermons''
==Births== *[[January 1]] – [[Isaac Reed]], English Shakespearean editor (died [[1807 in literature|1807]]) *[[March 25]] – [[William Combe]], English writer, poet and adventurer (died [[1823 in literature|1823]]) *[[June 25]] – [[Johann Schweighäuser]], German classical scholar (died [[1830 in literature|1830]]) *[[September 14]] – [[James Wilson]], American pamphleteer and publisher (died [[1798 in literature|1798]]) *[[October 6]] – [[Johan Herman Wessel]], Norwegian author (died [[1785 in literature|1785]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Ralph Broome (pamphleteer)|Ralph Broome]], English pamphleteer (died [[1805 in literature|1805]]) *''Probable date'' – [[Mihály Bakos]] (Miháo Bakoš), Slovene hymnist and Lutheran minister (died [[1803 in literature|1803]])
==Deaths== *[[March 23]] – [[Jean-Baptiste Dubos]], French author (born [[1670 in literature|1670]]) *[[April 27]] – [[Nicholas Amhurst]], English poet and political writer (born [[1697 in literature|1697]]) *[[July 9]] – [[John Oldmixon]], English historian (born [[1673 in literature|1673]]) *[[July 14]] – [[Richard Bentley]], English scholar and critic (born [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[July 19]] – [[William Somervile]], English poet (born [[1675 in literature|1675]]) *[[November 24]] – [[Andrew Bradford]], American publisher (born [[1686 in literature|1686]])
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authoritycontrol}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1742 In Literature}} [[Category:1742 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 18th century in literature]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Alexander McQueen | logo = AlexanderMcQueenLogo.jpg | logo_size = 250px | type = Subsidiary of [[Kering]] ([[Euronext]]: [https://www.euronext.com/en/products/equities/FR0000121485-XPAR KER FP]) | foundation = {{start date and age|1992}} | founder = [[Alexander McQueen]] | location_city = [[London]] | location_country = United Kingdom | key_people = Emmanuel Gintzburger
(CEO)
[[Sarah Burton]]
(Creative Director) | industry = Fashion | products = | revenue = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | homepage = {{URL|www.alexandermcqueen.com}} | footnotes = | owner = [[Kering]] }} ''' Alexander McQueen''' is a British luxury [[fashion house]] founded by designer [[Alexander McQueen]] in 1992. Its current creative director is [[Sarah Burton]].{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/runway/mens-fall-collections-2014/review/alexander-mcqueen?src=n/newsAlert/20140107-3 | title=Alexander McQueen Men's RTW Fall 2014 | work=Women's Wear Daily | date=7 January 2014 | accessdate=7 January 2014}} ==History== [[File:Alexander McQueen last show dress V&A museum.jpg|thumb|An Alexander McQueen dress from his last show, on display at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], London, in 2009.]] [[File:Alexander McQueen Savage Beauty Show the Met NYC 2011.jpg|thumb|A display from "Savage Beauty", a retrospective of Alexander McQueen designs at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York City, 2011.]] Alexander McQueen brand was founded by designer Alexander McQueen in 1992.{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=9916944 |title=Alexander McQueen Trading Limited: Private Company Information |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |accessdate=6 November 2010}} It was by the suggestion of [[Isabella Blow]] that McQueen use his middle name for the label.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-1306692/Isabella-Blows-BIG-discovery-Finding-Sophie-Dahl-making--betrayal-prot-g-Alexander-McQueen-led-fatal-downfall.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Detmar | last=Blow | title=Isabella Blow's BIG discovery: Finding Sophie Dahl should have been the making of her – but betrayal by protégé Alexander McQueen led to a fatal downfall | date=27 August 2010}} The house's early collections developed its reputation for controversy and shock tactics (earning the title "[[l'enfant terrible]]" and "the hooligan of English fashion"), with trousers aptly named "[[Low-rise jeans|bumsters]]" and a collection entitled ''Highland Rape''.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1483241/Ban-for-low-trousers-gains-support.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Tom | last=Leonard | title=Ban for low trousers gains support | date=10 February 2005}}{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/fashion/article7023806.ece|title=Profile: Alexander McQueen, the 'hooligan' of English fashion|work=The Times|accessdate=11 February 2010 | location=London | date=11 February 2010|first=Sadie|last=Gray}} Alexander McQueen staged lavish and unconventional runway shows, such as a recreation of a shipwreck for his Spring 2003 collection, Spring 2005's human chess game, and the Fall 2006 show, ''Widows of Culloden'', which featured a life-sized hologram of supermodel [[Kate Moss]] dressed in yards of rippling fabric.{{cite news | author=Bridget Foley| title=Hail McQueen|url=http://www.wmagazine.com/fashion/2008/06/alexander_mcqueen| work=W magazine | date=June 2008 | accessdate=21 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081120030502/http://www.wmagazine.com/fashion/2008/06/alexander_mcqueen| archivedate= 20 November 2008 | deadurl= no}} In total, McQueen designed 36 collections for his London label, including his MA graduate collection.Claire Wilcox: Alexander McQueen. London 2015, S. 303, {{ISBN|9781 85177 827 0}} During his time as head designer, McQueen was awarded the title "[[British Designer of the Year]]" four times between 1996 and 2003;{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8511115.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Designer Alexander McQueen dies | date=11 February 2010}} he was also appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]] and named International Designer of the Year by the [[Council of Fashion Designers of America|Council of Fashion Designers]] in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.handbag.com/fashion/alexander-mcqueen-commits-suicide/v1 |title=Alexander McQueen dies |publisher=Handbag.com |first=Leisa |last=Barnett |date=11 February 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216021227/http://www.handbag.com/fashion/alexander-mcqueen-commits-suicide/v1 |archivedate=16 February 2010 }} In December 2000, the [[Gucci]] Group acquired 51% of his company and appointed him as Creative Director{{cite web|author =05/11/2010 17:36 |url=http://www.ppr.com/en/brands/gucci-group/alexander-mcqueen |title=Alexander McQueen > Gucci Group > Présentation et Chiffres clés |publisher=Ppr.Com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} before launching stores in London,{{cite web|url=http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_London.aspx |title=Store Locator, London |publisher=Alexander McQueen |date=17 March 2003 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025074332/http://alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_London.aspx| archivedate= 25 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} Milan,{{cite web|url=http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_Milan.aspx |title=Store Locator, Milan |publisher=Alexander McQueen |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025102801/http://alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_Milan.aspx| archivedate= 25 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} New York,{{cite web|url=http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_NewYork.aspx |title=Store Locator, New York |publisher=Alexander McQueen |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025102556/http://alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_NewYork.aspx| archivedate= 25 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} Los Angeles{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbuildingsdirectory.com/project.cfm?id=745 |title=Alexander McQueen Flagship Store, Los Angeles |publisher=World Buildings Directory |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718113814/http://www.worldbuildingsdirectory.com/project.cfm?id=745 |archivedate=18 July 2011 }} and Las Vegas. On 31 October 2011, Alexander McQueen opened its first store in Beijing with a runway show.[http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_LasVegas.aspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917075556/http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/us/en/servicePages/storeLocator_LasVegas.aspx|date=17 September 2010}} Following the take over, the brand's catwalk presentations were relocated from London to Paris, beginning with the Spring/Summer 2002 collection with ''The Dance of The Twisted Bull'' on 6 October 2001.{{cite web|author1=Mari Davis |author2=Tom Massey |author3=Boyd Davis |url=http://www.fashionwindows.com/fashion_designers/alexander_mcqueen/S021.asp |title=Alexander McQueen Spring 2002 Paris Pręt-á-Porter |publisher=Fashionwindows.com |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707092709/http://www.fashionwindows.com/fashion_designers/alexander_mcqueen/S021.asp |archivedate=7 July 2010 }} Alexander McQueen launched its first menswear collection in Spring/Summer 2005{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/show.aspx/catwalk-report/id,1402 |title=Alexander McQueen Menswear – Catwalk report – Milan Spring/Summer 2005 |work=Vogue UK |date=29 June 2004 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611130550/http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/show.aspx/catwalk-report/id%2C1402 |archivedate=11 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and continues to show its collections during [[Milan Fashion Week]]. The company launched its first women's pre-Spring collection on the runway with its men's collection on 22 June 2008{{cite web|author=Tim Blanks |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/2009RST-AMCQUEEN |title=Alexander McQueen Resort 2009 Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=22 June 2008 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101022044905/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/2009RST-AMCQUEEN/ |archivedate=22 October 2010 }} and has since continued releasing [[cruise collection]]s since Spring 2010.{{cite web|author=Laird Borrelli-Persson |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/2010RST-AMCQUEEN |title=Alexander McQueen Resort 2010 Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=17 July 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616042756/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/2010RST-AMCQUEEN/ |archivedate=16 June 2010 }} Alexander McQueen launched an online store in the US in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.ftape.com/media/?p=4702 |title=Alexander McQueen UK Online Store Launch | F.TAPE | Fashion Directory |publisher=F.TAPE |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213200935/http://www.ftape.com/media/?p=4702 |archivedate=13 February 2010 }} This was later expanded with an online store for the UK market in 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.catwalkqueen.tv/2010/01/alexander_mcque_21.html |title=Catwalk Queen: Alexander McQueen launches online store |publisher=Catwalkqueen.tv |date=15 January 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424015935/http://www.catwalkqueen.tv/2010/01/alexander_mcque_21.html |archive-date=24 April 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} McQueen's suicide was announced on the afternoon of 11 February 2010.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1250249/Alexander-McQueen-commits-suicide.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first1=Rebecca | last1=Camber | first2=Sara | last2=Nathan | title=British fashion icon Alexander McQueen commits suicide days after death of his beloved mother | date=12 February 2010}} At the time of his death, the company had debts of [[pound sterling|£]]32 million{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/mcqueens-legacy-swamped-by-debt/story-e6frg6so-1225831983974 |title=McQueen's legacy swamped by debt |work=The Australian |date=19 February 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23807301-alexander-mcqueen-label-will-continue-despite-debts-of-pound-32m.do |title=Alexander McQueen label will continue despite debts of Ł32m |work=London Evening Standard |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100221090439/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23807301-alexander-mcqueen-label-will-continue-despite-debts-of-pound-32m.do |archivedate=21 February 2010 }} despite posting profits from handbag sales in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://dalje.com/en-lifestyle/alexander-mcqueen-boasts-with-profit/128436 |title=Alexander McQueen Boasts With Profit – Fashion – Lifestyle |publisher=Dalje.com |date=2 March 2008 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120811121103/http://dalje.com/en-lifestyle/alexander-mcqueen-boasts-with-profit/128436 |archivedate=11 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }} [[File:Alexander McQueen dress photo 2011.jpg|thumb|Alexander McQueen brand dress, 2011.]] ==McQ== On 27 July 2006, the company launched a lower-priced diffusion line '''McQ'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.fashionwiredaily.com/first_word/news/article.weml?id=19 |title=Alexander McQueen Launches Lower Priced McQ Line |publisher=Fashionwiredaily.com |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101028162451/http://fashionwiredaily.com/first_word/news/article.weml?id=19| archivedate= 28 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} The new line carries men's and women's ready-to-wear and accessories, was exclusively designed by Lee Alexander McQueen, manufactured and distributed worldwide by SINV SpA under the terms of a five-year licence agreement with Alexander McQueen.{{cite web|url=http://www.kitmeout.com/fashion/mc_q_jeans.php |title=McQ – Alexander McQueen – ready-to-wear denim |publisher=Kitmeout.com |date=4 November 2005 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100921200446/http://kitmeout.com/fashion/mc_q_jeans.php| archivedate= 21 September 2010 | deadurl= no}} Promoted as a denim line, the focus of McQ is a youthful target market.{{cite web|author1=Mari Davis |author2=Tom Massey |author3=Boyd Davis |url=http://www.fashionwindows.com/fashion_designers/alexander_mcqueen/denim.asp |title=Alexander McQueen Set To Be The New Denim King With 'McQ' |publisher=Fashionwindows.com |date=8 November 2005 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110425064343/http://www.fashionwindows.com/fashion_designers/alexander_mcqueen/denim.asp |archivedate=25 April 2011 }} The Spring/Summer 2011 was the final collection in collaboration with SINV SpA. Pina Ferlisi was appointed as the creative director for the line in June 2010.{{cite web |author=Ella Alexander |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100623-pina-ferlisi-creative-director-mcq.aspx |title=Pina Ferlisi creative director McQ |work=Vogue UK |date=23 June 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626204010/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100623-pina-ferlisi-creative-director-mcq.aspx |archivedate=26 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }} Following the expiration of the contract with SINV SpA with the Spring/Summer 2011 collection, the brand announced on 11 October 2010 that it would take control of the McQ diffusion line by creating a new internal team with the creative direction of Pina Ferlisi, under the leadership of Alexander McQueen creative director [[Sarah Burton]].{{cite web |author=Jessica Bumpus |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/101011-alexander-mcqueen-takes-control-of-.aspx |title=Alexander McQueen takes control full control of McQ |work=Vogue UK |date=11 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101014153517/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/101011-alexander-mcqueen-takes-control-of-.aspx |archivedate=14 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|last=Banks |first=Libby |url=http://www.mydaily.co.uk/2010/10/11/alexander-mcqueens-sarah-burton-is-back-in-control-at-mcq/ |title=Alexander McQueen's Sarah Burton is back in control at McQ: MyDaily UK |publisher=Mydaily.co.uk |date=11 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} For the first campaign for the re-acquired line, photographer Niall O'Brien collaborated with McQ by driving across the American Northwest capturing images, which evoked the McQ attitude.[https://archive.is/20120919061629/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/110323-mcq-springsummer-201112-campaign-.aspx McQ spring/summer 2011–12 campaign Tumblr (Vogue.com UK)]. ''Vogue''.uk (23 March 2011). In August 2011, the company announced it would launch its first McQ standalone boutique in London in 2012.[http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2011/08/05/mcq-store-opening-in-london McQ store opening in London (Vogue.com UK)]. ''Vogue''.uk (5 August 2011). In November 2011, it announced that McQ would be presented at London Fashion Week for the first time in February 2012, and that the new four-storey Georgian townhouse boutique will stock womenswear, menswear, and accessories.[http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2011/11/23/mcq-to-show-during-london-fashion-week McQ to show during London Fashion Week (Vogue.com UK)]. ''Vogue''.uk (23 November 2011). == Collaborations == Between 1996 and 2001, Alexander McQueen collaborated with jeweller [[Shaun Leane (jeweller)|Shaun Leane]] on bespoke jewellery pieces for the catwalk presentations.{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/fashion/fashion_motion/mcqueen_leane/index.html |title=Alexander McQueen & Shaun Leane – Victoria and Albert Museum |publisher=Vam.ac.uk |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100506043737/http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/fashion/fashion_motion/mcqueen_leane/index.html |archivedate=6 May 2010 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.shaunleane.com/page/Collaborations_Alexander_McQueen |title=Collaborations – Alexander McQueen |publisher=Shaunleane.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} In January 2003, Alexander McQueen collaborated with perfumer Jacques Cavallier{{cite web|url=http://www.fragrantica.com/perfume/Alexander-McQueen/Kingdom-1195.html |title=Kingdom Alexander McQueen Perfume |publisher=Fragrantica.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} to launch his first fragrance '''Kingdom''', which was launched on the designer's birthday 17 March.{{cite web|url=http://www.fashionunited.co.uk/news/alexandermc.htm |title=Alexander McQueen launches first perfume: Kingdom |publisher=Fashionunited.co.uk |accessdate=6 November 2010}} A limited edition version of the fragrance was launched in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.fragrantica.com/perfume/Alexander-McQueen/Kingdom-Limited-Edition-2794.html |title=Kingdom Limited Edition Alexander McQueen Perfume, a women's fragrance (2004) |publisher=Fragrantica.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The company launched its second fragrance, '''My Queen''' three years later in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://perfumesmellinthings.blogspot.com/2005/11/perfume-review-alexander-mcqueen-my.html |title=Perfume-Smellin' Things Perfume Blog: Perfume Review: Alexander McQueen My Queen |publisher=Perfumesmellinthings.blogspot.com |date=2 November 2005 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} On 10 October 2003, Alexander McQueen collaborated with [[Michael Clark (dancer)|Michael Clark]] to stage the Spring 2004 collection.{{cite web|author =Sarah Mower |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/S2004RTW-AMCQUEEN/ |title=Alexander McQueen Spring 2004 Ready-to-Wear Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=10 October 2003 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101030031344/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/S2004RTW-AMCQUEEN/| archivedate= 30 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} On 15 October 2003, Alexander McQueen collaborated with [[Björk]] at [[Fashion Rocks]] where the Fall 2003 collection was presented at the [[Royal Albert Hall]].{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/mcqueen-found-dead-on-eve-of-his-mothers-funeral-1897131.html?action=Popup&ino=20 | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Arifa | last=Akbar | title=McQueen found dead on eve of his mother's funeral | date=12 February 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://specials.bjorkish.net/fashionrocks/ |title=Fashion Rocks |publisher=Specials.bjorkish.net |date=15 October 2003 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} In 2004, Alexander McQueen collaborated with [[Safilo]] via a licensing deal to launch an eyewear range.{{cite web|url=http://www.2020mag.com/ViewContent/tabid/136/content_id/481/Default.aspx |title=> What;s New |publisher=2020mag.com |date=23 January 2007 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101204055614/http://www.2020mag.com/ViewContent/tabid/136/content_id/481/Default.aspx| archivedate= 4 December 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.safilo.com/en/2-alexander-mcqueen.php |title=Alexander McQueen – Safilo Group spa |publisher=Safilo.com |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110105034021/http://www.safilo.com/en/2-alexander-mcqueen.php |archivedate=5 January 2011 }} The 2010 collection featured the house's trademark skull detail.{{cite web|url=http://www.opticalnewsdaily.com/?p=2036 |title=Alexander McQueen Eyewear Fall 2010 Preview |work=Optical News Daily |date=30 April 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The same year, the company collaborated with [[American Express]] to launch a limited-edition version of its ultra-exclusive Centurion Card.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-118106237.html |title=American Express puts McQueen in the black.(News)(Centurion Card designed by Alexander McQueen)(Brief Article) – Design Week |date=27 May 2004 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The card is available by invitation only to AMEX Platinum card members.{{cite web|author1=Mari Davis |author2=Tom Massey |author3=Boyd Davis |url=http://www.fashionwindows.com/news/2004/amex.asp |title=Alexander McQueen For American Express |publisher=Fashionwindows.com |date=12 April 2004 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110425064117/http://www.fashionwindows.com/news/2004/amex.asp |archivedate=25 April 2011 }} To launch the card, McQueen hosted a retrospective of his collections from 1995 till Fall 2003.{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/2004-06/040604-mcqueen-in-the-black.aspx |title=Alexander McQueen hosts a spectacular one-off show and auction for Amex in London – and buys everything himself |work=Vogue UK |date=4 June 2004 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611130629/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/2004-06/040604-mcqueen-in-the-black.aspx |archivedate=11 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} In 2005, Alexander McQueen collaborated with [[Puma AG|Puma]] to produce a line of men's and women's footwear launched in Spring 2006.{{cite web|url=https://www.dexigner.com/news/4689 |title=Puma Announces Collaboration with Alexander McQueen |publisher=Dexigner |date=3 June 2005 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The '''Alexander McQueen PUMA''' line is founded on the union of tradition and technology, with juxtaposing influences.{{cite web|url=http://alexandermcqueen.puma.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060225161239/http://alexandermcqueen.puma.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 February 2006 |title=Alexander McQueen PUMA |publisher=Alexander McQueen PUMA |date=17 March 1969 |accessdate=6 November 2010 }} In 2008, the line's Fall 2009 collection was fully expanded to include men's and women's clothing and accessories,{{cite web|url=http://www.londonnet.co.uk/fashion/fashion-news/alexander-mcqueen-puma |title=Alexander McQueen PUMA Unveils Autumn/Winter 2009 Apparel Collection |publisher=LondonNet |date=20 January 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} with a collaboration with film director [[Saam Farahmand]] to produce a 4-minute movie ''Ghost'' as an ad campaign for the collection.{{cite web|url=http://flux.net/flux-super-8-saam-farahmand |title=Super 8: Saam Farahmand " Flux – A global creative community celebrating film, art, music and design |publisher=Flux |date=10 August 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://slamxhype.com/fashion/puma-x-alexander-mcqueen-ghost-commercial/ |title=Puma x Alexander McQueen "Ghost" Commercial |publisher=Slamxhype |accessdate=6 November 2010}} In 2007, Alexander McQueen became the first brand to participate in [[MAC Cosmetics|MAC's]] promotion of cosmetic releases created by fashion designers.{{cite web|url=http://www.temptalia.com/mac-cosmetics-alexander-mcqueen-collection-inspiration |title=MAC Cosmetics – Alexander McQueen Collection & Inspiration |publisher=Temptalia.com |date=2 October 2007 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The collection was released on 11 October and reflected the looks used on the Autumn/Winter McQueen catwalk. The inspiration for the collection was the [[Elizabeth Taylor]] movie ''[[Cleopatra (1963 film)|Cleopatra]]'', and thus the models sported intense blue, green, and teal eyes with strong black liner extended Egyptian-style.{{cite web|url=http://thegloss.com/beauty/mac-cosmetics-alexander-mcqueen-collection/ |title=MAC Cosmetics Alexander McQueen Collection " : TheGloss – A gloss on beauty, fashion, style, love and more |publisher=TheGloss |date=6 October 2007 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} In 2008, Alexander McQueen collaborated with mass market retailer [[Target Corporation|Target]] as '''McQ Alexander McQueen for Target'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.fabsugar.com/Target-Chooses-Alexander-McQueen-Designer-Collaborations-Series-2466541 |title=Target Chooses Alexander McQueen For Designer Collaborations Series |publisher=Fabsugar.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The company was the first collaboration between Target and an international designer.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/retail-news/mcqueen-on-target-1863903?full=true |title=McQueen on Target – Retail Store and Industry News |work=Women's Wear Daily |accessdate=6 November 2010}} McQueen cited Leila Moss of [[The Duke Spirit]] as his muse for the collection.{{cite web |author=Leisa Barnett |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/081105-alexander-mcqueen-to-launch-target-.aspx |title=Alexander McQueen to launch Target line |work=Vogue UK |date=5 November 2008 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611130346/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/081105-alexander-mcqueen-to-launch-target-.aspx |archivedate=11 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The collection was launched on 4 March 2009,{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/mar/01/image/ig-mcqueen1 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Max | last=Padilla | title=Target's Alexander McQueen line to hit the racks | date=1 March 2009}} with the band playing at the launch party.{{cite web|url=http://themusic.fm/2009.02.25/duke-spirit-alexander-mcqueen |title=The Duke Spirit Discusses Collaboration With Designer Alexander McQueen |publisher=TheMusic.FM |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101220231435/http://themusic.fm/2009.02.25/duke-spirit-alexander-mcqueen| archivedate= 20 December 2010 | deadurl= no}} The same year, Alexander McQueen collaborated with [[Samsonite]] to produce luggage formed using a mould of a human ribcage and sternum on the front and spine on the back.{{cite web|url=http://www.designboom.com/weblog/cat/8/view/4588/samsonite-black-label-collection-by-alexander-mcqueen.html |title=samsonite black label collection by alexander mcqueen |publisher=Designboom.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} Other pieces in the collection apply animal patterns like crocodile to the bags skin using laser cutting technology.{{cite web|url=http://www.luggagesource.com/IBS/SimpleCat/Shelf/ASP/Hierarchy/0R09.html |title=Samsonite Black Label Alexander McQueen |publisher=Luggagesource.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} With the catwalk presentations, Alexander McQueen collaborated with [[Philip Treacy]] to produce hats for the Spring 2008 collection,{{cite web|author =Sarah Mower |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/S2008RTW-AMCQUEEN/ |title=Alexander McQueen Spring 2008 Ready-to-Wear Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=6 October 2007 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101021004418/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/S2008RTW-AMCQUEEN/| archivedate= 21 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} and again with the Fall 2009 collection.{{cite web|url=http://jewelry.about.com/od/fashionshowjewelry/ig/Outrageous-Hats/ |title=Philip Treacy Hats at Alexander McQueen Fashion Show – Paris Fashion Week – Outrageous Hats at Paris Fashion Week |publisher=Jewelry.about.com |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101006034127/http://jewelry.about.com/od/fashionshowjewelry/ig/Outrageous-Hats/| archivedate= 6 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} During first semester of 2009, McQueen also collaborated with dancer Sylvie Guillem, director Robert Lepage and choreographer Russell Maliphant, designing wardrobe for theater show "Eonnagata", directed by Robert Lepage. The film "Sylvie Guillem, on the edge" produced by French production company A DROITE DE LA LUNE, traces whole history of the creation of the show, from first rehearsals which took place in Quebec until world premiere which was held in 2008 at Sadler's Wells theater in London.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global/2009/mar/03/eonnagata-sadlers-wells-dance-review-judith-mackrell |title=Eonnagata |publisher=theguardian.com |accessdate=27 June 2015}} On 6 October 2009, the company collaborated with [[SHOWstudio.com|SHOWstudio]] to stream its Spring/Summer 2010 collection ''Plato's Atlantis'' live on the company's website.{{cite web |url=http://showstudio.com/stream/alexander_mcqueen_live |title=Streams |publisher=SHOWstudio |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101102114021/http://showstudio.com/stream/alexander_mcqueen_live |archivedate=2 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.trendhunter.com/trends/alexander-mcqueen-showstudio |title=Live-Streaming Runway Shows – Alexander McQueen and SHOWstudio Collaborate for Spring 2010 (VIDEO) |publisher=Trendhunter.com |date=16 January 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101114013641/http://www.trendhunter.com/trends/alexander-mcqueen-showstudio| archivedate= 14 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} The shoes from that collection were later featured on the SHOWstudio website.{{cite web|url=http://showstudio.com/project/objectfetish/mcqueen_shoes |title=Object Fetish |publisher=SHOWstudio |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101102114842/http://showstudio.com/project/objectfetish/mcqueen_shoes| archivedate= 2 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} The same year, the company collaborated with [[Unkle]] who produced music for the McQ Autumn/Winter 2009 collection{{cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/news/2009/04/20/unkle-for-mcq-by-alexander-mcqueen-autumnwinter-2009/ |title=UNKLE For McQ By Alexander McQueen Autumn/Winter 2009 |publisher=Highsnobiety.com |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} titled '''[[End Titles... Stories for Film#McQ|McQ]]'''. The collaboration was a success, and was extended a second season for the McQ Spring/Summer 2010 collection where the promotional CD was given out in a McQ press goodie bag.{{cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/news/2010/01/30/mcq-spring-2010-press-pack-including-unkle-record/ |title=McQ Spring 2010 Press Pack including UNKLE Record |publisher=Highsnobiety.com |date=30 January 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} In June 2010, [[Visionaire]] magazine's 58th issue, titled '''Spirit: A Tribute To Lee Alexander McQueen''', was released as a tribute to the late founder.{{cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/news/2010/05/05/video-visionaire-magazine-issue-58-spirit-a-tribute-to-lee-alexander-mcqueen/ |title=Video: Visionaire Magazine Issue 58 "Spirit" – A Tribute to Lee Alexander McQueen |publisher=Highsnobiety.com |date=5 May 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The issue featured images and discussions with editors who had met McQueen in 2003 to discuss the collaboration which never materialised.{{cite web|url=http://www.fabsugar.com/Tribute-Lee-Alexander-McQueen-Visionaire-Magazine-9041255 |title=A Tribute to Lee Alexander McQueen by Visionaire Magazine |publisher=Fabsugar.com |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101030093119/http://www.fabsugar.com/Tribute-Lee-Alexander-McQueen-Visionaire-Magazine-9041255| archivedate= 30 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} The issue also features contributions from [[Lady Gaga]], [[Steven Klein (photographer)|Steven Klein]], [[Nick Knight (photographer)|Nick Knight]] and [[Mario Testino]]{{cite web |author=Ella Alexander |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100708-visionaire-alexander-mcqueen-tribut.aspx |title=Visionaire Alexander McQueen tribute book |work=Vogue UK |date=8 July 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100711141203/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100708-visionaire-alexander-mcqueen-tribut.aspx |archivedate=11 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }} Only 1,500 numbered copies were made, with pages made from seeded paper, which will sprout wildflowers once planted signifying the ongoing legacy of McQueen.{{cite web|url=http://www.agent2magazine.com/covet/visionaire-58-tribute-to-lee-alexander-mcqueen/ |title=VISIONAIRE 58: TRIBUTE TO LEE ALEXANDER MCQUEEN |publisher=AGENT2 Magazine |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} [[File:Alexander McQueen Cupsole Sneaker in yellow suede.gif|thumb|Alexander McQueen Cupsole Sneaker in yellow suede]] == Controversies == Alexander McQueen first caused controversy with his Spring/Summer 1995 collection which featured his signature "bumster trousers". At the time, the trousers were described as indecent as they barely covered the natural downward curve of the buttocks.{{cite web|url=http://fashion.ukfirst.com/A%20Cut%20Below%20the%20Waist/BelowTheWaist.html |title=Below the Waist |publisher=Fashion.ukfirst.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}} He followed this by entitling his Autumn/Winter 1995 collection ''Highland Rape'' which he explained was about the "rape" of Scotland by the English, a subject that had a personal resonance as his family is of Scottish descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/arts/mcqueen_a.html |title=>> arts >> McQueen, Alexander |publisher=glbtq |date=17 March 1969 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215194353/http://www.glbtq.com/arts/mcqueen_a.html |archivedate=15 February 2010 }} The collection featured tattered dresses made of scraps of tartan and chiffon and a tampon-strewn skirt.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/02/12/alexander-mcqueen-fashion-feminism-obituary-opinions-contributors-raquel-laneri.html |title=His Dark Materials |work=Forbes |date=12 February 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |first=Raquel |last=Laneri |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031005215/http://www.forbes.com/2010/02/12/alexander-mcqueen-fashion-feminism-obituary-opinions-contributors-raquel-laneri.html |archivedate=31 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} In 1998, Alexander McQueen photographed [[Aimee Mullins]] and sent her down the catwalk with intricately carved wooden legs – making her the first amputee to ever be featured on the catwalk.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2003/may/25/features.magazine87 | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Dee | last=O'Connell | title=What happened next? | date=25 May 2003}} For the untitled Spring/Summer 1999 catwalk show, [[Shalom Harlow]]'s white cotton dress was sprayed by car robots as she was spun around a platform.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703382904575059654022817776 | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=William | last=Lyons | title=Shock, Controversy and Beauty | date=11 February 2010}} Animal rights activists and heavy police presence due to a reported bomb scare were present at the Autumn/Winter 2000 ''Eshu'' catwalk show, due to the extensive use of fur and leather in the collection.{{cite web |url=http://www.widemedia.com/fashionuk/fashion/catwalk-archive/lfw-aw00/mq.html |title=fashionUK >> london fashion week a/w 2000–2001 >> Alexander McQueen |publisher=Widemedia.com |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718043226/http://www.widemedia.com/fashionuk/fashion/catwalk-archive/lfw-aw00/mq.html |archive-date=18 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} McQueen was accused of [[misogyny]] following the Autumn/Winter 2009 ''The Horn of Plenty'' catwalk show{{cite web|author=Sarah Mower |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/F2009RTW-AMCQUEEN |title=Alexander McQueen Fall 2009 Ready-to-Wear Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=10 March 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009205035/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/F2009RTW-AMCQUEEN/ |archivedate=9 October 2010 }} where models with huge, overdrawn red and black lips were compared to a blow-up sex doll and hats made from found objects and rubbish like aluminium cans and duct tape implied models themselves were trash.{{cite web|last=Flaherty |first=Erin |url=http://www.allure.com/beauty/blogs/reporter/2009/03/backstage-alexander-mcqueen-mi.html |title=Alexander McQueen: Misogyny or Artistry?: Daily Beauty Reporter: Beauty Reporter Blog |work=Allure |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100924145503/http://www.allure.com/beauty/blogs/reporter/2009/03/backstage-alexander-mcqueen-mi.html| archivedate= 24 September 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://jezebel.com/5472257/is-he-for-or-against-women-alexander-mcqueen-and-the-female-form |title="Is He For Or Against Women?" Alexander McQueen and the Female Form |publisher=Jezebel.com |date=15 February 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} Similarly, the Autumn/Winter 2010 ''An Bailitheor Cnámh'' menswear catwalk show featured men in weird masks and netted headgear that alluded to sadomasochism or bondage, and one of the suits was printed with human skulls and bones.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/02/12/alexander-mcqueen-fashion-feminism-obituary-opinions-contributors-raquel-laneri_2.html |title=His Dark Materials |work=Forbes |date= 12 February 2010|accessdate=6 November 2010 |first=Raquel |last=Laneri}} For the Spring/Summer 2010 ''Plato's Atlantis'' catwalk show, models refused to wear the now iconic 12 inch high armadillo shoes due to safety fears.{{cite web|url=http://www.myfashionlife.com/archives/2009/12/23/models-refused-to-walk-in-mcqueens-armadillo-shoes/ |title=Models refused to walk in McQueen's armadillo shoes |publisher=My Fashion Life |accessdate=6 November 2010}} One of the models who refused, had fainted in the Spring/Summer 2009 ''Natural Dis-tinction Un-natural Selection'' catwalk show after being squeezed into a corset which was too tight.{{cite web|url=http://www.graziadaily.co.uk/fashion/archive/2009/12/22/models-refused-to-wear-those-mcqueen-shoes.htm |title=Grazia Fashion: Models refused to wear THOSE McQueen Shoes! |publisher=Graziadaily.co.uk |accessdate=6 November 2010}} [[Lady Gaga]] wore a pair in her music video for ''[[Bad Romance#Music video|Bad Romance]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.catwalkqueen.tv/2009/11/cq_watch_lady_g_1.html |title=Catwalk Queen: CQ Watch: Lady Gaga rocks Alexander McQueen's 10-inch shoes in "Bad Romance" video |publisher=Catwalkqueen.tv |date=11 November 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2010}}{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2009/11/11/2009-11-11_lady_gagas_on_fire_in_her_bad_romance_video__or_her_dude_is_at_any_rate.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | first=Issie | last=Lapowsky | title=Lady Gaga's on fire in her 'Bad Romance' video – or her man friend is, at any rate | date=13 November 2009}} and created a version in chocolate encrusted with sparkly sprinkles for her Christmas shop in 2011.[http://www.alligator.org/blogs/lifestyle/ifthechoofits/article_75e3e090-1a3d-11e1-b43f-001cc4c03286.html Barneys' Gaga's Workshop features Alexander McQueen chocolate shoe, Ray-Ban sunglasses and other fashion items – The Independent Florida Alligator: If The Choo Fits]. Alligator.org (29 November 2011). [[Selfridges]] department store in London caused controversy when they unveiled a window display showing one of his designs being hanged from the gallows.{{cite web|url=http://showbiz.sky.com/fashion-news |title=Selfridges' Controversial McQueen Window Display |publisher=[[Sky Showbiz]] Fashion-News |date=14 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100711004129/http://showbiz.sky.com/fashion-news |archivedate=11 July 2010 }} The store later apologised, saying that "presenting a fashion item from the new Alexander McQueen collection hanging was never intended to be linked to the designer's untimely death or how he died."{{cite web|author = Mel |url=http://www.catwalkqueen.tv/2010/07/selfridges_apol.html |title=Catwalk Queen: Selfridges apologises for McQueen window display |publisher=Catwalkqueen.tv |date=25 July 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101115170827/http://www.catwalkqueen.tv/2010/07/selfridges_apol.html| archivedate= 15 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} In October 2010, [[Hells Angels|The Hell's Angels]] filed a lawsuit against the company for "misusing its trademark [[Hells Angels#Insignia|winged death heads symbol]]"{{cite web |author=Ella Alexander |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/101027-hells-angels-sue-alexander-mcqueen.aspx |title=Hells Angels sue Alexander McQueen |work=Vogue UK |date=27 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101030145629/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/101027-hells-angels-sue-alexander-mcqueen.aspx |archivedate=30 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} in several items from its Autumn/Winter 2010 collection. The lawsuit was widely reported across all media,{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/caf87e7a-e153-11df-90b7-00144feabdc0.html?ftcamp=rss |title=/ Companies / Personal Goods – Hells Angels sue luxury fashion house |work=Financial Times |date=27 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101027185930/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/caf87e7a-e153-11df-90b7-00144feabdc0.html?ftcamp=rss| archivedate=27 October 2010| deadurl= no}}fhttp://web.orange.co.uk/article/quirkies/Hells_Angels_sue_Alexander_McQueen{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Hells-Angels-Takes-Alexander-McQueen-to-Court-for-Copyright-Infringement-163513.shtml |title=Hells Angels Takes Alexander McQueen to Court for Copyright Infringement – Softpedia |publisher=News.softpedia.com |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101101093617/http://news.softpedia.com/news/Hells-Angels-Takes-Alexander-McQueen-to-Court-for-Copyright-Infringement-163513.shtml| archivedate= 1 November 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Jeffrey |first=Don |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-26/hells-angels-sue-saks-mcqueen-design-over-trademark-update1-.html |title=Hells Angels Sue Saks, McQueen Design, Over Trademark |publisher=Bloomberg |date=26 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031002218/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-26/hells-angels-sue-saks-mcqueen-design-over-trademark-update1-.html |archivedate=31 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} and is also aimed at [[Saks Fifth Avenue]] and [[Zappos.com]], which stock the US$1,595 "Hells Angels [[Jacquard weaving|Jacquard]] Box Dress" and "Hell's Angels knuckle duster ring" which bear the symbol which is protected by the US Patent and Trademark Office since at least 1948.{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-1324242/Alexander-McQueen-sued-Hells-Angels-winged-death-head-trademark.html?ito=feeds-newsxml | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Tamara | last=Abraham | title=Hells Angels sue Alexander McQueen over winged death head trademark | date=27 October 2010}} The US$2,325 "Hell's Angels Knuckleduster Box clutch" handbag{{cite web|url=http://celebrifi.com/gossip/Hells-Angels-Sue-Alexander-McQueen-Label-Over-Winged-Deaths-Head-Symbol-3822386.html |title=Hells Angels Sue Alexander McQueen Label Over Winged Death's Head Symbol – Hells Angels Gossip |publisher=Celebrifi.com |date=27 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} and US$$560 "Hells Angels Pashmina" scarf{{cite web|author =Verena von Pfetten |url=http://www.styleite.com/media/hells-angels-alexander-mcqueen/ |title=Hell's Angels vs Alexander McQueen – Lawsuit DETAILS |publisher=Styleite |date=29 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101106101149/http://www.styleite.com/media/hells-angels-alexander-mcqueen/| archivedate= 6 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} was also named in lawsuit.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/caf87e7a-e153-11df-90b7-00144feabdc0.html |title=/ Companies / Personal Goods – Hells Angels sue luxury fashion house |work=Financial Times |date=27 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101030023827/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/caf87e7a-e153-11df-90b7-00144feabdc0.html |archivedate=30 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} The lawyer representing Hells Angels claimed "This isn't just about money, it's about membership. If you've got one of these rings on, a member might get really upset that you're an imposter."{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39867980/ns/business-us_business/ |title=Hells Angels set for rumble on the catwalk – Business – U.S. business – Retail |publisher=MSNBC |date=27 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101104183555/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39867980/ns/business-us_business/| archivedate= 4 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} The group is demanding that the companies stop producing the products, recall any items in distribution and pay damages totalling three times whatever profit they made on the products.{{cite news|author =Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/hells-angels-take-retailer-designer-to-court/article1773944/ |title=Hells Angels take retailer, designer to court |work=The Globe and Mail |date=26 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101030130526/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/hells-angels-take-retailer-designer-to-court/article1773944/| archivedate= 30 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} SAKS refused to comment, Zappos had no immediate comment and the company's parent company, PPR, could not be reached for comment. The company settled the case with the Hell's Angels after agreeing to remove all of the merchandise featuring the logo from sale on their website, stores and concessions and recalling any of the goodies which have already been sold and destroying them.{{cite web|url=http://www.graziadaily.co.uk/fashion/archive/2010/11/04/mcqueen-settles-with-hell-s-angels.htm |title=Grazia Fashion: McQueen Settles with Hells Angels |publisher=Graziadaily.co.uk |date=27 September 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101107075747/http://www.graziadaily.co.uk/fashion/archive/2010/11/04/mcqueen-settles-with-hell-s-angels.htm| archivedate= 7 November 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|author =Verena von Pfetten |url=http://www.styleite.com/media/mcqueen-hells-angels-settlement/ |title=Alexander McQueen – Hell's Angels – SETTLEMENT |publisher=Styleite |accessdate=6 November 2010|date=3 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101106033150/http://www.styleite.com/media/mcqueen-hells-angels-settlement/| archivedate= 6 November 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|last=Cowles |first=Charlotte |url=http://nymag.com/daily/fashion/2010/11/alexander_mcqueen_settles_with.html |title=Alexander McQueen Settles With Hells Angels by Agreeing to Destroy Merchandise With Skull Logo – The Cut |work=New York |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101106003355/http://nymag.com/daily/fashion/2010/11/alexander_mcqueen_settles_with.html| archivedate= 6 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} Similarly, costume designer Jany Temime was exposed for copying a dress from the Autumn/Winter 2008 collection ''The Girl Who Lived in the Tree'', for her work on ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1|Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]''.{{cite web|last=Wang |first=Connie |url=http://www.refinery29.com/did-the-designer-harry-potter-steal-designs-from-alexander-mcqueen.php |title=Harry Potter Steals Alexander McQueen Designs |publisher=Refinery29.com |date=25 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101107172801/http://www.refinery29.com/did-the-designer-harry-potter-steal-designs-from-alexander-mcqueen.php| archivedate= 7 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} Temime had claimed that she "wanted it to be a witch wedding dress but not a Halloween dress. The dress is white but it needed to have something fantastic to it. So there is the phoenix [motif], the bird, which is a symbol of love in a way because there is rebirth, love never dies, it is born again." However, the birds on the McQueen original were actually peacocks, and although Temime did manage to change the crest on the bird's heads to make them more 'phoenixy', she neglected to alter any other detail of the birds, including their rather obvious peacock feathers. {{cite news| url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/columns/belinda-white/TMG8087321/Harry-Potter-costume-designer-accused-of-stealing-Alexander-McQueen-design.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Harry Potter costume designer accused of stealing Alexander McQueen design | first=Belinda | last=White | date=26 October 2010}} The story was widely reported by the fashion media.{{cite web|url=http://www.graziadaily.co.uk/fashion/archive/2010/10/26/harry-potter-bride-marries-in-knock-off-alexander-mcqueen.htm |title=Grazia Fashion: Harry Potter Bride Marries in Knock-Off Alexander McQueen ! |publisher=Graziadaily.co.uk |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://jezebel.com/5672772/harry-potter-knocks-off-alexander-mcqueen |title=Harry Potter Knocks Off Alexander McQueen |publisher=Jezebel.com |accessdate=6 November 2010}}{{cite web|last=Fenner |first=Justin |url=http://www.styleite.com/media/harry-potter-alexander-mcqueen/ |title=Harry Potter – Alexander McQueen Knockoff – PHOTOS |publisher=Styleite |date=25 no}}{{cite web |author=Kirsten Chang |url=http://ellegirl.elle.com/girl-gossip/2010/harry-potter-dress-resembles-alexander-mcqueen-gown/ |title=Harry Potter Wedding Dress Looks Familiar… |work=Elle 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://allieiswired.com/archives/2010/10/harry-potter-designer-thieve-alexander-mcqueen-designs/ |title=Harry Potter Designer Thieve Alexander McQueen Designs? |publisher=Allie is Wired |date=26 October 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101102000932/http://allieiswired.com/archives/2010/10/harry-potter-designer-thieve-alexander-mcqueen-designs/| archivedate= 2 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} ==Post-Lee Alexander McQueen through today== On 18 February 2010, Robert Polet, the president and chief executive of the Gucci Group, announced that the Alexander McQueen business would carry on without its founder and creative director.{{cite news|url=http://www.wwd.com/business-news/mcqueen-business-to-continue-despite-founders-suicide-2492441?src=nl/newsAlert/20100218|title=McQueen Business to Continue Despite Founder's Suicide|work=Women's Wear Daily|first=Miles|last=Socha|date=18 February 2010|accessdate=18 February 2010}} He also added that a McQueen collection would be presented during Paris Fashion Week. On 27 May 2010, Sarah Burton, McQueen's right hand design aide since 1996, was announced as the new creative director of the Alexander McQueen brand,{{cite web|url=http://www.elleuk.com/news/fashion-news/new-creative-director-of-alexander-mcqueen-is-revealed |title=Elle News | New Creative Director of Alexander McQueen Is Revealed |publisher=Elleuk.com |date=27 May 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809080344/http://www.elleuk.com/news/fashion-news/new-head-of-mcqueen-is-revealed|archivedate=9 August 2011}} with further plans to launch a men's underwear collection in June 2010.{{cite web|author =Sarah Deeks |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100527-sarah-burton-is-named-new-creative-.aspx |title=Sarah Burton is new creative director at Alexander McQueen |work=Vogue UK |date=27 May 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} The underwear line featured iconic prints from the McQueen archive and the logo on the waistband,{{cite web|author=Gq.Com |url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/entertainment/articles/2010-04/08/gq-editors-picks-alexander-mcqueen-underwear |title=GQ editor's picks: Alexander McQueen underwear |work=GQ |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412140340/http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/entertainment/articles/2010-04/08/gq-editors-picks-alexander-mcqueen-underwear |archivedate=12 April 2010 }} with a percentage of the launch collection of Alexander McQueen underwear to be given to various AIDS charities around the world.{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/24/alexander-mcqueen-underwe_n_511301.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Hilary | last=Moss | title=Alexander McQueen Underwear Collection To Be Released in June (PHOTOS, POLL) | date=24 March 2010}} Burton launched her first menswear show ''Pomp and Circumstance'' under the McQueen brand in June 2010 to generally positive reviews, which noted how low-key the event was.{{cite web|author =Tim Blanks |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/S2011MEN-AMCQUEEN/ |title=Alexander McQueen Spring 2011 Menswear Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=20 June 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101022212410/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/S2011MEN-AMCQUEEN/| archivedate= 22 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} She launched the brand's womenswear resort collection shortly after,{{cite web|url=http://www.signature9.co.uk/fashion/sarah-burton-flies-solo-for-mcqueen |title=Sarah Burton Flies Solo for McQueen | Signature9 UK |publisher=Signature9.co.uk |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010}} which was praised for lightness and having 'a woman's touch'.{{cite web|author=Tim Blanks |url=http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/2011RST-AMCQUEEN |title=Alexander McQueen Resort 2011 Collection on Style.com: Runway Review |publisher=Style.com |date=21 June 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104173543/http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/2011RST-AMCQUEEN/ |archivedate=4 November 2010 }} Burton showed her first womenswear show on 5 October 2010 in Paris, where she said her vision for the brand would be "lighter".{{cite web |author=Ella Alexander |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100928-sarah-burton-changes-mcqueen.aspx |title=Sarah Burton changes McQueen |work=Vogue UK |date=28 September 2010 |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101001080830/http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/daily/100928-sarah-burton-changes-mcqueen.aspx |archivedate=1 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} The show was praised for being one of the strongest shows at Paris Fashion Week,[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i92UpeBH383tt2z8IGBbnwdESG2QD9ILP4R00?docId=D9ILP4R00] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010161839/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i92UpeBH383tt2z8IGBbnwdESG2QD9ILP4R00?docId=D9ILP4R00|date=10 October 2010}} "full of McQueen trademarks and ideas" and a "far more optimistic sensibility".{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/show.aspx/catwalk-report/id,9981 |title=Alexander McQueen Ready-To-Wear – Catwalk report – Paris Spring/Summer 2011 |work=Vogue UK |accessdate=6 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010120557/http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/show.aspx/catwalk-report/id%2C9981 |archivedate=10 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} [[Michael Jackson]]'s "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" was played at the finale of the show.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/oct/05/alexander-mcqueen-sarah-burton | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Imogen | last=Fox | title=Alexander McQueen protege Sarah Burton steals the show in Paris | date=5 October 2010}} Creative director [[Sarah Burton]] designed the dress worn by [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] during her wedding to [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]] on Friday 29 April 2011.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13236617 | publisher=BBC News | title=Royal wedding: What are they saying about the dress? | date=29 April 2011}} An analysis of online chatter shows that Alexander McQueen creates the most intense feelings of brand passion amongst wedding dress designers in the NetBase Brand Passion Index.[[NetBase]] [http://www.netbase.com/blog/general/brand-passion-index-here-comes-the-bride/ Brand Passion Index for Wedding Dress Designers]. 22 June 2011. [[The Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City hosted a posthumous exhibition of McQueen's work in 2011 titled ''[[Savage Beauty (exhibition)|Savage Beauty]]''. Despite being open for only three months, it was one of the most popular exhibitions in the museum's history.{{cite web|title=McQueen Show Beats Jeff Koons's Record at the Met, Right at the Buzzer|url=http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2011/08/07/mcqueen-show-beats-jeff-koonss-record-at-the-met-right-at-the-buzzer/|work=ArtInfo (''In the Air'' blog)|accessdate=8 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809073805/http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2011/08/07/mcqueen-show-beats-jeff-koonss-record-at-the-met-right-at-the-buzzer/|archivedate=9 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} The exhibition was so successful that Alexander McQueen fans and industry professionals worldwide began rallying at Change.org to "Please Make Alexander McQueen's Savage Beauty a Traveling Exhibition" to bring honour to McQueen and see his vision become a reality: to share his work with the entire world.[http://www.globalfashionwire.com/press/en/63898/Petition_For_Alexander_McQueen_Exhibit_To_Tour_Gains_Momentum.html Petition For Alexander McQueen Exhibit To Tour Gains Momentum]. Globalfashionwire.com (25 August 2011). The exhibition [[Savage Beauty (exhibition)|Savage Beauty]] was brought to the Victoria & Albert Museum in London from 14 March 2015 to 2 August 2015. [http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/exhibitions/exhibition-alexander-mcqueen-savage-beauty/ Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty at the Victoria & Albert Museum]. vam.ac.uk. On 28 November 2011, Sarah Burton won the Designer of the Year at the 2011 [[British Fashion Awards]].[http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2011/11/28/british-fashion-awards-2011-winners British Fashion Awards 2011 Winners] ''Vogue''. (UK) (28 November 2011). As of January 2014, Harley Hughes is Alexander "McQueen's head of men's wear design" during the Fall 2014 fashion show. After the show, both Sarah Burton, the creative director, and Harley Huges, took a bow to the public. In July 2015, [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], wore an all-cream Alexander McQueen outfit for [[Princess Charlotte of Cambridge]]'s christening.{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/entertainment/celebrity/princess-charlottes-christening-see-the-photos/ss-AAcAb3o|title=Princess Charlotte's christening: See the photos!|website=www.msn.com|accessdate=12 January 2018}} In May 2016, at [[UNESCO]] Headquarters, Alexander McQueen brand won [[Prix Versailles]] for its [[rue Saint-Honoré]] boutique, in Paris.{{cite web|url=http://diversum.net/fichiers/File/%28en%29_Prix_Versailles_30-05-2016.pdf|title=Prix Versailles press release, 30 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/alexander-mcqueen-prix-versailles-10439871/|title=Alexander McQueen Store Wins Prix Versailles|first=Alex|last=Wynne|date=31 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2018}} == Ownership and shareholdings == Kering Holland N.V == Creative Directors == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Director !! Tenure |- | [[Sarah Burton]] || 2010–present |- | [[Alexander McQueen|Lee McQueen]] || 2002-2010 |} == Retail Stores == AMQ and McQ operated by Alexander McQueen Ltd. and Kering S.A., with YOOX S.p.A. as online retailer since 2011.{{Cite web | url = http://www.alexandermcqueen.com/ | title = Alexander McQueen | website = www.alexandermcqueen.com - Online Store | access-date = 2016-02-26 }} Asia: 23 Europe: 7 (London (2), Milan, Moscow (2), Paris, & Vienna) Middle East: 3 (Abu Dhabi & Dubai (2)) United States: 6 (Dallas, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, & San Francisco) === Other/Department stores === Harrods Harvey Nichols Joyce Saks Fifth Avenue Bergdorf Goodman Selfridges Neiman Marcus Bloomingdale's Barney's New York Nordstrom Tsum == List of Alexander McQueen collections == Alexander McQueen collections each featured a title revolving around the specific theme for each collection and show. The tradition ended for Fall 2010 with McQueen's death, and subsequent collections were launched without titles.
